urn:contentItem:5XC8-RV31-DY08-346P-00000-00BBC Weekend News - 10:15 PM GMT2019-10-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:20:43ZLexisNexisU.K. REGIONAL TVNewsBBC Weekend News - 10:15 PM GMT

The latest national and international news.

Speech to text transcript:

This copy is computer generated. Text will vary in accuracy due to speaker dialect and audio quality issues.

blood or a scar of some sort. Like a grooming process, especially on Instagram, because you follow one hash tag to another hash tag and it's grooming that person to self-harm more, consider suicide more, and maybe even take action on that. It just needs to be shut down. I just... There are children literally dying every day from something that we can help prevent and we are not doing it.

I don't understand it. At 5.38, he found her lifeless body... Mallory Grossman was just 12 when she ended her own life. Her mother, Diane, believes she was bullied to death, in part on social media. Now, she tours the country, sounding a warning. One high school had nine suicides in one year. Nine children. Hindsight is cruel. Hindsight is very cruel. That's the toughest thing to cope with. Yes, it is. That, to me, is hindsight, that... I share that people think that the worst day of my life was the day that she died and I say, "No, it's the day before, it was the day before." There's a million things you wish you'd done differently. We have a moral responsibility to protect our youth. If I could sit down at the table with Mark Zuckerberg, could I make your product better? Could I make it safer? What a great way for you to attaboy each other and high five each other in the boardroom, if you actually put in infrastructure in a system to protect children. Keep up that work. You too. San Francisco and Silicon Valley, where big tech has flourished. But is it time for the industry to be reined in? It's amazing to me that as a father, you are willing... Definitely yes, says America's biggest charity dealing with online child safety. This is a huge problem and the lack of responsibility of the social media platforms is absolutely mind-boggling and absolutely disgraceful, so it is clear to me that they can and should be regulated. Journey's end, thoughts of home and, of course, of Molly. Molly is with me every day. I think all of her friends and family think about her frequently. She always wanted to help people. So I am pretty certain that she would be pushing for change so that young people were safer when they were online and that if they need help they could more easily find it. Ian Russell ending Angus Crawford's report. And if you've been affected by any of the issues raised and would like details of organisations which offer advice and support, then go to our website - bbc.co.uk/actionline. Or you can call for free, at any time, to hear recorded information on 0800 066 066. And tomorrow night, we'll have an exclusive interview with the head of Instagram, who tells us about the impact Molly's death has had on Silicon Valley. Now, with the day's sport, here's Lizzi Greenwood Hughes at the BBC Sport Centre. Thanks, Clive. Good evening. Wales' head coach Warren Gatland says it wasn't to be after his side just missed out on a first World Cup final. They were beaten 19-16 in their semifinal by South Africa who'll now play England for the title next weekend. Andy Swiss reports from Yokohama. The anticipation was deafening, Wales fans hoping for history, could they join England in the World Cup final? Their passion was obvious. But they would need poise as well.

and I couldn't agree with Rasmus more on this issue. I'm a huge advocate of freedom of expression and freedom of speech, and the big tech companies are doing their best to show that they can do this regulation and they're doing more so during Covid than they ever have, and, you know, I commend some of their efforts. There are certain things we should certainly remove - child pornography, for example, or suicide videos.

There's all sorts of things that we should take down. I think those are a lot easier than when it gets to expressions of a policy or other forms that, you know, you can't even go through all the different variations. But I think there's going to be a lot of discussions in countries over the next year, especially around things like Section 230, which is a particular law in the United States that grants immunity to these platforms, and whether that holds or doesn't hold, that will really kind of give us direction on where we're going. But my overall opinion about this is that we have to be very careful about having governments control this, because it's a slippery slope. Once you start giving them that kind of control, then it can lead to some of the things that Rasmus said. urn:contentItem:546V-SG81-DYG3-102W-00000-00BB&T Corp at BancAnalysts Association of Boston Conference: To Buy or Not to Buy: That is the Question - Final2011-11-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:20:43ZLexisNexis110311a4231746.746BB&T Corpat BancAnalysts Association of Boston Conference: To Buy or Not to Buy: That is the Question - Final

Corporate Participants

* Clarke Starnes

BB&T Corp.- CRO

Conference Call Participants

* Gerard Cassidy

BancAnalysts Association of Boston - President

Presentation

GERARD CASSIDY, PRESIDENT, BANCANALYSTS ASSOCIATION OF BOSTON: All right, our second presentation is BB&T Corporation. As many of you know, it's one of the largest financial institutions in the United States. The Company is in over 12 states with over 1800 branches. As we've seen over the years with BB&T, the Company has grown both organically and through acquisitions and certainly they had the announcement earlier this week acquiring -- purchased an assumption of the deposits and loans of BankAtlantic.

With us today is Clarke Starnes. He is the Chief Risk Officer. He's had this position since July of 2009. Prior to that, he was the Chief Credit Officer. Clarke has been with the Corporation since the early 1980s and has had numerous positions throughout the Company over this time period. With that, I will turn it over to Clarke. Clarke.

CLARKE STARNES, CRO, BB&T CORP.: Thank you, Gerard and good morning, everyone. Thank you for the opportunity to share what I believe is a very positive update and outlook for BB&T. I see a lot of familiar faces out there, but I would remind you all that BB&T is a very high performing, growth-oriented regional bank holding company. What drives our business strategies and our low-risk, long-term risk appetite is a very unique value system. We believe this has created, in our opinion, the premiere Mid-Atlantic and Southeastern banking franchise with nearly 1500 -- I'm sorry -- nearly 1800 financial centers and about $167 billion in assets.

Remind everyone a key tenet of our growth strategy is we believe that brand presence, market presence and distribution of density is very important. So it's our stated objective to be in the top five in all the markets we operate. We believe that's very important to have an efficient general banking operation. And what you'll notice is that we're basically there in the majority of our markets with excellent opportunities for growth in our new markets such as in Texas.

I do want to talk about how we distribute our general banking services. We think it's a unique distribution model. We've operated a community bank, local-oriented, high service distribution platform for nearly 25 years. A lot of people talk about local decision-making and community bank style of distribution; we leave it every day. We believe we are the best in it and that distribution is supported by large bank operational risk management oversight.

I'm going to talk in a minute about, and give you a little more color around some high-growth opportunities for BB&T. While we're very well known for our general banking operations, over the last 10 or 15 years, we believe we've built up an impressive non-bank business as well on our largest single non-bank businesses -- our insurance brokerage operation, number six in the US. We just announced this morning another addition to that group through the acquisition of the Precept Group in Irvine, California. Think that's a great, long-term complimentary fit for us. It does [EV] and healthcare consulting. We bring national distribution to their model. So we think that's a nice meaningful addition there. And we also have a number of non-bank lending operations that I'm going to dive down a little bit deeper on today because they're providing excellent growth opportunities.

The theme behind my remarks today is around strong balanced performance. Look, we're not naive. There's a lot of risk, structural issues in the system, in the economy, in the regulatory environment, the fractured political landscape. We are not focused on those. We are aware of those, we're managing that, but what we would rather focus on are the opportunities.

And I think when you look at our third-quarter results and our outlook for 2012, you're going to see that we are paying off with our long-term investments to drive revenue, very strong fundamental core loan and deposit growth, excellent performance in de-risking our CRE concentration and improving our credit trends and even with all of the issues out there today, we don't see any backup at this point. I'll speak more about that in a moment.

And then again while others are forced into large direct cost-cutting programs, we would rather focus on reconceptualizing our business and generating more relative revenue for the dollars we spend. And what we believe you all ought to get out of that is that this strategy will enhance long-term shareholder value.

A quick look at the third quarter, we were quite pleased. This was the strongest earnings in three years. The EPS up 73%, $0.52. Strong revenue growth, our operating revenues linked-quarter were up 3.6%. I will show you that. That was driven by good strong loan growth primarily. Credit quality, a very bright story for us.

The noteworthy item -- nonperforming assets down on an accelerated basis almost 12%, loan growth 4.3% in total, over 7% if you exclude our targeted runoff portfolios in ADC and the Colonial covered assets. And then excellent deposit growth as we are trying to lower the relative cost of our funding mix, as well as improve our liquidity ratios in anticipation of the Basel requirements.

If you look at the loan growth side, a very positive story. I think the highlight here is that it was broad-based. So what we are beginning to see is the payback of a number of long-term investments. I'm going to mention a little more about in a moment. Strong C&I growth, strong across all retail channels, cards, auto, mortgage and particularly we are proud that we finally turned our consumer branch-oriented retail that was noteworthy. Strong outlook there and then very, very strong results in the sub. So as a result, despite this slowdown in the economy and the challenges there, we are actually raising our forecast. So we think our growth will accelerate in the fourth and beyond and will position us for 2012.

I do want to dive down today and spend just a little extra time on two key growth areas in the lending side. I get a lot of questions about our results around corporate or middle-market lending and the growth of our non-bank subsidiary businesses. So I want to clarify what our strategy there is. We think this is a very positive story for BB&T and a unique opportunity for us.

Remind everyone, BB&T has a conservative risk appetite. One of the things we feel very good about is we don't follow the herd and just run to what's available. And I would suggest to you that's a lot of what you are seeing today in the marketplace, a lot of folks are chasing syndicated lending, indirect auto or what's available, not necessarily with a long-term commitment or expertise in those businesses.

Corporate lending for us -- and we define corporate more what you guys would call basic middle-market lending. Kelly King four or five years ago made a strategic decision that we needed to substantially invest in an underpenetrated area for us given our emerging regional status and our higher ratings. So we have never really played very much in this space. And so we dedicated enormous incremental investment over the last four or five years into the front-line producers, specialized expertise around primarily seven industry verticals that we write research for. It's very complementary to our corporate bank and our broker-dealer operations and you see those segments there.

We invested in the front room, we also invested in the syndications infrastructure, as well as dedicated specialized risk management in the credit area before we launched this program. And so we've been methodically moving forward since that time and now, given the market disruption, it's really coming back to pay off for us because we are being asked in the credits. Companies who were spooked by fractured syndication groups during the downturn, they weren't reliable partners. They view BB&T in that light.

What we're not doing is chasing every big league table deal that is out there. That is not who BB&T is. So, for example, one of our risk appetite exclusions is we don't do big tech-sponsored leveraged deals. And so a little factoid for you is that, year-to-date, in our shared credit production, almost 80% of the deals are a total deal size of $750 million or less.

And so the point is we are lending to companies we know, industries we have expertise in and where we have a meaningful opportunity to share in the noncredit economics. While others talk about having their credit teams help them take larger hold positions, we are doing the opposite. So it's very granular exposures. Our average commitment is only about $30 million, but you see the benefit. We're seeing substantial growth in that area. I would tell you most of the growth is coming in the new markets we acquired in Colonial -- Alabama, Florida and Texas and nationally along those specialized industry verticals. So it's a great opportunity for growth, but I will assure you that we are going to manage the risk extraordinarily well.

The other area I want to talk about today is our specialized lending group. I do get a lot of questions about this and again, this is a similar story. I actually created this group, organized it for the bank in 1999. And we've actually been in a number of these businesses since the mid to late '90s. And so John Allison previously looked forward and obviously was concerned about where would the great opportunities be in general banking in the future and suggested that we ought to think longer term about other ways to generate growth in more nontraditional areas.

And so the way we approached that is there were a number of particularly non-bank providers of specialty services that our clients were using. And so what we decided was to focus on those platforms, which have a pretty good integration tie-in to our general bank and invest in these platforms.

And so the way I think you all ought to think about this is a portfolio of companies. We have very strict limits and levels of appetite around this, so today it represents about a little under 8% of our portfolio. I don't ever see it being an outsized exposure. Maybe it is 10% or 12% tops. So we've got particular sublimits for each of the categories, but the way I think about it is you've got kind of a bifurcated respect from here, so you've got the highest risks, which are the consumer finance platforms. The most noteworthy is our nonprime auto business, which by the way is performing the best in the Company history, lowest loss rates ever, lower than 4% in nonprime. I suggest that nobody is doing that out there.

We also -- on the other end of the spectrum though is our low risk P&C insurance premium finance business. That would be more or less a 5 to 20 basis point loss rate business. So what we want to do is blend that risk and have an appropriate mix to get very predictable results. We did have very fast growth rates this quarter, but a lot of that was driven by seasonality in our P&C premium finance business. I would think more along the lines of the sustainable growth rate for this platform is probably in the high single digits to low double digits for the foreseeable future.

The benefit we think this gives us is geographic distribution. It's very granular and it nicely complements our general bank and frankly has been somewhat of a countercyclical hedge as the general bank portfolios stressed during the downturn. So again, we think these are two noteworthy areas of opportunity that are very unique to BB&T.

Looking at the deposit side, like a lot of banks, we've had strong deposit growth, but for us our focus has been around not just generating excess deposits, but to try to improve our funding mix. And you can see that we had a nice linked-quarter reduction in funding costs. We think that will continue into the future. That will help us maintain some of the -- or slow down some of the deterioration in the margin as we move forward.

We also work very hard and Daryl Bible has done a great job in positioning our balance sheet to be very, very well positioned for the liquidity requirements on the upcoming Basel front. So that was part of the design in the strategy is to increase those funding benefits there on the deposit side and we'll talk about that more in just a second.

So looking at overall credit trends for the quarter, very strong. This is the fourth consecutive linked quarter that we've had pretty much broad-based improvement in all areas and what gives me comfort as we look forward particularly is the lower rates of inflow on the watch list, the early-stage area in the NPA inflows. So we think with our heavy focus on reducing our existing nonaccruals by the fact that we are not reloading that you're going to see continued improvement as we move forward.

You can see again the noteworthy 12% or so decrease in nonperforming assets for the quarter. We think that is sustainable as we move through the fourth and into '12. Unless we see a substantial backup in the economy, our guidance would be continued improvement as we move forward. And obviously the real benefit of that will be the earnings leverage we will get out of that lower credit cost.

I would note -- what is noteworthy for us, it is kind of interesting, is that we are now on the early stage, the 30 to 89, 90 plus, we are back at 2006 levels pretty much across the board. So again, very hard work to produce those results.

From a loss content standpoint, we're right where we told you we would be. Our guidance for you was that, through the end of the year, we would break the 150 mark. You can see we effectively did that in the second and the third on a core basis, 144 basis points for the quarter. And I felt very good about that because, again, to have that kind of loss rate performance while we were aggressively liquidating nonperforming assets was a very, very positive outcome.

I do want to talk about one point that we think was maybe a little less understood on the call and that was around a particular charge we took for impaired performance in the Colonial portfolio. That was -- just to remind you all, that was no P&L event, but basically you have complex accounting around the impairment analysis of these pools. We have 41 distinct pools that we have to recast every quarter and certain ones of those pools can be impaired and we have to provide for those. And remember we provide for those, we have an 80% offset from the FDIC loss share agreement. So what you saw this quarter was about $53 million of charges against previously established reserves.

So the way I think about it is more or less a balance sheet reclass because those $53 million worth of loans already after effect of the reserve and the allowance had a net carrying value of zero. So all we are really doing now is we've actually realized the losses. They have emerged, so we have to reclass those off the balance sheet. The way you do that is to charge -- through the charge-off against the allowance.

Now what that meant to us is, the way you ought to think about the reserve benefit we got in the quarter, is our release, excluding that event, was $123 million against the core non-Colonial portfolio. That is very similar to the level of release we did in the second quarter. So we really didn't accelerate our releases in Q3 and the continued improvement that we are seeing in the portfolio we think is going to allow us continued credit leverage in reducing provisions over the near term.

There are a couple though. While releases are important as credit recovers, it is a big earnings driver for BB&T, we also have, again, we think a unique opportunity. You all know our stated strategy around working through the assets a little more long term than others through this cycle. As a result, we have a large OREO book. And so the benefit we see as we look forward is there is a large carrying cost for that book, much larger relatively than others. That's an additional earnings lever we can and will pull as we move forward that could substantially provide an earnings lift as we go into '12 and beyond.

And so what you saw in the third quarter was a distinctive shift. While we have been working methodically the book down, very steady sales each quarter, we kind of embarked on a new approach as we went through the third. We think the time is right for us. There's good market demand for these assets. And so what we decided to do was to go ahead and accelerate some of the dispositions. And the other thing is we're working very hard not to take title. So you notice much lower inflows in the third quarter compared to previous quarters.

So what you should think about in all of this is that we are going to reduce this book in a more accelerated fashion several ways. We are going to take less through inflows, not take title. Where it's appropriate, we are going to look at the economic trade-off of whether taking a higher front-end mark would help us accelerate disposition and lower run rate. We think the trade-off will be very positive and we think we can do that without hurting our short-term earnings. So stay tuned for that. You saw that in the third quarter, a little higher OREO expense levels. We actually took a little bit more liquidity mark to help get started on this strategy. And had we not chosen to do that OREO, expenses actually would have been down. So that's what this represents as we move forward.

So what we think that will do for us, again, we've said this before, the headline number for us, we believe conservatively non-provision-related, we probably have north of $700 million in expenses that we will ultimately be able to get out of our cost structure as the NPA levels come down. And we've kind of lifted those out for you, but obviously the biggest driver is OREO. The point I would make is we are just beginning to realize some of that $700 million. So the bulk of that opportunity lies ahead as we go into '12 and beyond.

From a margin outlook, we still have good loan pricings benefiting us. We're right where we told you we'd be, the 4% range for the -- 4.09% for the third and we think will be about 4% for the fourth. We do want to add a little guidance for 2012 the 3.85% to 3.95% levels. What is really driving some of the decrease in the margin is primarily mix where we've added investment securities for liquidity, reasons we think most of those purchases will be done toward the end of the fourth quarter.

And then the other big driver is the Colonial accretion running down. But remember, we do want to make the point that, as the accretion runs down so does the negative offset in our non-interest income. And just to remind you all, for the first nine months of the year, that FDIC loss share offset was about $243 million. And as we go into 2012 and beyond, you'll see a $10 million or $15 million improvement in the offset that helps against that lower accretion.

On the fee income side, obviously just heard the gentleman talk about product redesign. We are very focused on that, but as Kelly said on the call, you stay in the house when it's storming outside and so we have been purposeful in a very methodical approach to looking at our product redesign. We have identified about $385 million of impact with Durbin, Reg E and posting order changes. We've worked very hard through product reconceptualization to offset we believe going forward over time, about 50% of it. And we're committed to working with our clients in a very client-friendly accepting way to find the other revenue.

Do want to make a point about efficiency and cost programs. Kelly mentioned on the call that we are not announcing a specific program name or targeting a cost-cutting number. We're approaching it differently. The way we want to think about it is this. We get the calls and the resumes every day from the company, employees of the companies that are going through very draconian programs and they're scared to death about their job. We know those kinds of approaches might work short term, but we think they are very risky long term to how you run your business.

So what Kelly has challenged our executive team to do is to reconceptualize from the bottoms up. So what I can tell you is going on is a very thorough program. Every senior manager in the bank is presenting to an optimization committee that Daryl Bible is heading. What's exciting about it is our employees feel very empowered and enthusiastic. I sat through a couple of presentations literally yesterday where those ideas are being presented to this committee. That committee will give a recommendation to executive management and we will begin implementation of those ideas as we go through the end of the fourth and into '12.

And we think the numbers will be meaningful, but we're not going to commit to a number because we believe that that's not the right approach for us. But I can assure you we are well focused on what we need to do to be highly efficient with all of the structural issues out there.

From a capital standpoint, obviously we feel very good. Basel III pro forma looks about 8.8% now. As we've said many times before, we've got four priorities in that order -- growth, number one, dividends, strategic opportunities and buybacks.

Do want to talk about the exciting transaction this week, BankAtlantic. A number of you guys I know have seen that. This very much is consistent with our strategy to be a top five player in the markets we serve. Frankly, for us, we haven't talked a lot about this out of the Colonial acquisition. The entry into Miami has actually gone very well for us. We sent two of our best bankers there and one of our best credit guys. We're really doing well. So this very much augments and enhances that distribution.

So it perfectly fit strategically for what we are trying to do there. It met our return aspirations very well, accretive immediately, meets our IRR hurdle. We think it was relatively well priced as far as the financial economics and most of all, it's a very low risk transaction as we've got a good bank/bad bank structure and on top of that, we've taken a 7% mark on the assets we are acquiring.

You can kind of see the pro formas there and why it's so important to us. It leaps us from number 14 to number 6 in that market. You can see the green BankAtlantic branches. Just a very, very nice fit for our existing franchise. So this was very, very positive. Employees are very enthusiastic. We've already met with the management and the new employees at BankAtlantic and they're ready to go.

So let me close here with a just a reminder again on how we started. We think we've got a very positive story for BB&T. We are focused on the opportunities, not the challenges. The long-term investments we've made are paying off. Our credit trends are improving substantially. We are very focused on rationalizing our business for the future and we believe that will allow us to drive shareholder value as we move forward.

So let me stop there, Gerard, and see what kind of questions I can answer.

Questions and Answers

GERARD CASSIDY: And Clarke, just a reminder to repeat the question.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: (inaudible - microphone inaccessible)

CLARKE STARNES: Yes, I think we've spent a lot of time talking about what does a normalized return look like and I think we talked you guys about eventually getting back well over 1 ROA and 15, 16 ROE, which is a doubling from where we are today. We have done a five-year forecast; we've looked at it incrementally. We believe the drivers are there to do that, earning asset growth, increased scale, big big reduction in credit costs. We are at 144 basis points of losses today. We think we can, on a long-term basis with our mix, be more down in the 60 to 80 basis points. So for us, the credit leverage is huge, as well as just improving our efficiency back to more normal levels for us. So despite the increased regulatory costs, we believe that those drivers will help us get to that over a reasonable period of time.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: (inaudible - microphone inaccessible)

CLARKE STARNES: Yes, the question is around reconciling or tying NPA reduction with the more aggressive OREO management and note sales and those sorts of things. And so what I would tell you is that, a year ago, we launched an aggressive note sales strategy for our commercial book. We put $2 billion in a warehouse and told you that we would liquidate that in about three or four quarters hopefully within the marks that we had established.

We successfully did that. I'm happy to report it's all gone. We were able to do that within the loss content numbers that I provided. And so what we are trying to do now is continue the inflow -- the reason we had to do that last year, we felt like we had to do it was we still had substantially high rates of NPL inflow. And so we knew without more aggressive action, we were not going to be able to stop the increase in non-performers without some more aggressive sales.

So we've been successful in doing that and that strategy has substantially lowered the NPLs, but also now with the rate of inflows substantially lower, we think we can turn our attention to accelerating disposition of the OREO. So what you will likely see is us much less willing to take title. And so what that looks like is resolving the credits while it's in the note form, that may look like some one-by-one sales or workouts with the borrower. That's what we've been doing very successfully; that will continue. That alone will drive a reduction in NPLs along with our normal sales of OREO.

But we believe by having less inflows and then turning our attention to again that economic tradeoff of whether we ought to accelerate sales, even if it means a higher current period mark because if you look at the leverage on it, it costs us 8% or 10% a year of the national balance just to manage the asset and then you've got large revaluation risk as you hold it going forward. And so even in some additional front-end mark, we think you'll get it back immediately on the run rate. So that is the way we think about it as we move into 2012.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: (inaudible - microphone inaccessible)

CLARKE STARNES: Excellent question. The good news is we believe we can do this without substantially increasing our charge-off. So we thank for the fourth quarter, you are going to be in about the 140 to 150 range even with the strategy and you should expect, in 2012, that our charge-offs will be lower. So we don't anticipate that this strategy will result in higher charge-offs than the guidance we have previously given you.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: Clarke, two questions related to asset (inaudible). First of all, the BankAtlantic purchase. Can you give us a little better color on the BankAtlantic credit quality and how you've looked at it and how much yield (inaudible) on the portfolio? And then secondarily, in terms of the specialty finance business, obviously that's growing a little bit faster now that (inaudible)?

CLARKE STARNES: Sure, fair question. One is around kind of the credit due diligence and insight into the BankAtlantic portfolio; the second around how we think about those credit trends over a long-term basis and managing those in the specialty finance area.

On the BankAtlantic book, I will tell you that we did a very thorough due diligence. We did a traditional due diligence. We looked at loan tapes and we actually sent a lot of people down to crack files the old fashion way. So we did a big sample and file review, so was not an abbreviated due diligence. We felt very good about it. They've worked very hard to bring down their problems and the way this deal is structured, as you all know, we didn't just leave nonperforming assets with the holdco; we actually moved all the watchlist assets. So all the performing criticized assets and classified assets were moved to the holdco and then on top of that, through due diligence, we identified not a large amount, but some additional assets they were calling performing that we would probably in our classifications rate as watchlist or nonaccrual. We excluded those as well and then we put a 7% mark on top of that.

And you have about a -- a portfolio that we're acquiring that's got about a 40% resi mortgage piece, 20% or so home equity, maybe 15%, a little under 20% CRE. So we think the bulk of the risk has been left behind. I'll be honest with you, I think we will do better -- I think we'll do substantially better than 7% mark, which is what our experience was with Colonial.

As it relates to the specialty businesses, we do try to manage those within a long-term loss rate. The way I think about those businesses, particularly the consumer finance pieces, which is probably what you're more concerned about, most of the commercial businesses here are very low risk, bank-like, is that they're not necessarily high risk businesses if they are managed well; they're high-loss rate businesses.

So for us, it's around managing the volatility in that. So when we look at our models and how we do stress-testing, we know how to calibrate the underwriting so that you tend to not have, if you do it well, the volatility in these businesses during shocks. And then the other benefit you get, a lot of these lend at the max legal rate. So when you go through tough times, while your loss rate goes up some, your spreads widen. So you get somewhat of a hedge there. So we think, overall, it's predictable and sustainable, but, to your point, we don't want to see outsized growth that could create risk that we are not comfortable with.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: (inaudible - microphone inaccessible)?

CLARKE STARNES: Question around how we derived or calibrated the 7% mark, what were our drivers? When we looked at this and we did our modeling, a couple of factors I will tell you that actually influenced the 7%. We probably could have done a lower mark, but didn't have real good visibility into, for example, in their home equity portfolio. You've got seconds behind somebody else's first. They don't really have good intelligence around performance of the first. So there is a little risk there.

And then on the resi portfolio, you have a level of IOs in there. It was also not -- I will tell you the resi portfolio is not Florida exclusively; this goes well beyond Florida. But you've got some IOs that haven't converted. While they're very seasoned, we looked within our models and shot some of that. And so those were the two principal areas that we raised our mark on; not so much the CRE. We know the CRE values pretty well in that market. We are working through those same kind of assets with Colonial.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: (inaudible - microphone inaccessible)

CLARKE STARNES: Yes. I mean the -- I think the way the (inaudible) and the holdco thinks about that is that there -- I think the balance is about $600 million roughly in criticized or nonperforming assets that they believe they've marked substantially and they're actually working through. We chose not to take those. They believe there is enough value beyond their mark that will more than cover over time their obligations and TruPS. And so that really was their strategy was to make sure there was enough -- there was enough asset value in the holding company to meet those liabilities and obviously we were not willing at all to take on that risk. Nancy.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: Yes, Clarke, could you just speak to --given that I guess you said you're expecting sort of 60 to 80 basis points for long-term loss rate. Where do you think your reserve is going to end up? Do you have any sense of what regulators -- how the regulators (inaudible) going forward?

CLARKE STARNES: Question is around -- we mentioned a 60 to 80 basis point long-term loss rate assumption and the question is outlook or comments around what a reserve level might look like with that kind of loss horizon. And I would tell you that, first and foremost, we don't really know. Some of the things that influence our thinking though is that just from a risk standpoint, we think that if you were in maybe the 2 times your loss rate range would be an appropriate long-term reserve. We are going to be conservative. So if you're on the high side of that, maybe that's the 160s. I have heard comments from some in the industry around whether the regulators are going to try to influence more of a floor on reserves coming out of the cycle and slow down the rate of releases. And I've heard whispers around things like a 2% floor might be in the cards.

But in our discussions with the regulators and obviously we look at the risk and we also have to think about what the new accounting guidance will be and all that uncertainty leads us to the conclusion we don't know yet. But our best guess right now is that for us that 2 times is probably appropriate.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: Do you have any sense of what timeframe -- in what timeframe you might be getting that guidance (inaudible)?

CLARKE STARNES: Nancy's question is around the sense of when we might have clarity around that. I think it's uncertain. I think as you go through '12, you'll know more. Again, FASB has got to clarify where they're coming from and then again the regulators have not been insistent upon any numbers at this point, particularly for us.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: (inaudible - microphone inaccessible)

CLARKE STARNES: Question is around there haven't been as probably as large a level of losses in the home equity portfolios as we would have predicted in this cycle or many would have predicted in this cycle. What events might change that or trigger bigger potential losses in the future? Our experience has been -- I can tell you our experience and this may well be similar to other places is that the bad actors or the strategic defaulters are pretty much gone and the people that are left, whether it's on the resi first side or whether it's on the home equity, generally want to pay if they can.

So I can tell you this, in our portfolio, the biggest driver is the rate of change in unemployment. So while HPI decline is a big factor too and certainly continued deterioration would cause more defaults, the biggest macro driver would be rate of change in unemployment.

The other thing that we also, common sense, but you see it in the modeling is those -- even in underwater resi and home equity portfolios, if there was original skin in the game, that performs better. So one of the things you really ought to look at is not just what the current LTV is is did they put something in it? And what we see is where there was down payment, even if at same LTV level to someone who didn't put a down payment, you have a different experience.

GERARD CASSIDY: Clarke, with that, we need to wrap up; we've run out of time. Thank you very much. Please join me in a round of applause.

CLARKE STARNES: Thank you very much.

Corporate Participants

BB&T Corporation- Senior EVP & Chief Information Officer

BB&T Corporation- President & COO

BB&T Corporation- Senior EVP & Chief Risk Officer

BB&T Corporation- Senior EVP & CFO

* David E. Hudson Weaver

BB&T Corporation- Senior EVP & President of Community Banking

* DontÃ¡ L. Wilson

BB&T Corporation- Senior EVP & Chief Digital & Client Experience Officer

BB&T Insurance Holdings, Inc. - Chairman and CEO

* Kelly Stuart King

BB&T Corporation- Chairman & CEO

BB&T Corporation- SVP of IR

BB&T Capital Markets Inc. - Senior Executive VP, Manager, Director, CEO of BB&T Securities and President of BB&T Securities

Conference Call Participants

* Betsy Lynn Graseck

Morgan Stanley, Research Division - MD

* Christopher William Marinac

FIG Partners, LLC, Research Division - Director of Research

* Geoffrey Elliott

Autonomous Research LLP - Partner, Regional and Trust Banks

* Gerard S. Cassidy

RBC Capital Markets, LLC, Research Division - Analyst

* James Hanna

Millennium Management LLC - Portfolio Manager

* John G. Pancari

Evercore ISI Institutional Equities, Research Division - Senior MD & Senior Equity Research Analyst

* Kenneth Michael Usdin

Jefferies LLC, Research Division - MD and Senior Equity Research Analyst

* Lana Chan

BMO Capital Markets Equity Research - MD & Senior Equity Analyst

* Matthew D. O'Connor

Deutsche Bank AG, Research Division - MD

* Michael Lawrence Mayo

Wells Fargo Securities, LLC, Research Division - MD, Head of U.S. Large-Cap Bank Research & Senior Analyst

* Saul Martinez

UBS Investment Bank, Research Division - MD & Analyst

Presentation

RICHARD BAYTOSH, SVP OF IR, BB&T CORPORATION: Good morning, and welcome to BB&T's 2018 Investor Day. My name is Rich Baytosh with Investor Relations.

Thank you to everyone who made a trip to Greensboro today and to those on the WebEx listening. We're very appreciative that you made it to the event, and thank you again for all of you who joined us yesterday for an evening at the Institute.

We trust you had an enjoyable time and learned about the mission. Regarding today's schedule, at registration, you received a brochure with the agenda for the day and a description of the exhibits. On your way into the auditorium, you'd noticed that the exhibits were open, and they will be open all day during breaks and during lunch, but not during the presentations. We encourage you to stop by and learn as much as you can about each of these exhibits.

Now some housekeeping items. Materials for each presentation will be uploaded to BBT.com, shortly before each presenter. There is a refreshment setup in the back of the room and also outside for your enjoyment. And there is also a device-charging station in the back of the room. And as you exit the room, there is one up to the right. We have breaks scheduled throughout the day at 10 -- just shortly before 10 A.M. and again at 2:15 P.M., and there will be a lunch at 11:45.

We have a full schedule today, and there will be time for Q&A at the end of the presentations with the entire executive management team.

And finally, we have our forward-looking disclosure statement shown on the screen as well as in Daryl Bible's presentation. The statement covers all presentations and the Q&A session.

Now with great pleasure, let me introduce our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Kelly King.

(presentation)

KELLY STUART KING, CHAIRMAN & CEO, BB&T CORPORATION: Our perspective is a very interesting concept. I hope that little video gives you just a way to think about your perspective on life. How many times do we get bogged down and focused and concerned about all the challenges and all the issues and all the problems we have and how tough life is for us. And then we got a different perspective, and we realized as how fortunate we are and how blessed we are. So we're very blessed, very thankful that you all are here. Thank you very much. Thank you to all of you that came last night. I hope your stay was enjoyable. Thank you, all of you for joining us on the webcast. We really appreciate you joining us as well.

So what we tried to share with you last night is that BB&T is a different company. We're a different bank. We really are focused on trying to make the world a better place to live, and we are doing everything we can in that context to execute on our vision and our mission and our values. Those are the 3 things about BB&T that are nonnegotiable, our vision, our mission And our values. That's important because everything else is negotiable. The world is changing -- the world is changing with blinding speed. We talked some about that last night, but I'll just reinforce to you that because the world is changing so fast, it is critically important for all that are going to survive and thrive to be willing to change in accord.

So BB&T, you're going to hear a lot today about the strategies and tactics. Last night, we talked about philosophy, today, we will talk about strategies and tactics.

You're going to hear us talk about Disrupt or Die. You're going to hear us talk about building the new banks. You're going to hear us talk about pruning the old bank. And you'll see the transitional of slow of that as we extract expense load from the old bank, that is not needed today, and invest heavily in the new bank, in digital, in new delivery platforms, in lots of new products that you're going to purchase, that you're going to hear about. So this whole idea is about helping you understand better how we are transitioning from the old bank to the new bank to be positioned to this new world in which we live and so very, very exciting, exciting tasks.

You're going to hear us talk about some key concepts. One of the things that you'll hear about is us working with a number of consultants. As we go across the business and reconceptualize and reconstitute our businesses. That's all a part of this "Disrupt or Die" strategy.

There are couple of head philosophies that I had over the years, and I hope you will hear threaded through this that I think are pretty powerful. One of those is, it is better to have 100% execution of an 80% idea than a 50% execution of 100% idea. In other words, it don't have to be exactly right, it just needed to be really, really well executed.

John Wooden used to say that his basketball team, every time, one of his new superstars would come in with all of his great personal plays and say, "Coach, we got to run my play." And coach would say, "No, we're going to run these plays," and then player would say, "Well, coach, you've been running these same plays for years. And everybody, when they come to play you, they know what your plays are going to be." He said, "That's all right, I'll write it down and give it to them. Here is the reason we're going to win because we will be better focused, better trained, better shaped, we will execute better, we will win every time even though they know exactly what our strategies are." BB&T is really focused on good strategies, but we're really, really focused on good execution.

Another key concept that you'll hear and that's threaded through all of these reconceptualization approaches, and this is a really important one and that is, every function in the organization should be performed by the person who is the least qualified, who can perform it effectively.

Every function in the organization should be performed by the person who is the least qualified, who can perform it effectively. That is the concept of empowerment. So if you think about that letting the least qualified person do the job versus the most qualified, which is what happens in most companies, you're constantly pushing down empowerment, which means you're constantly growing people.

So we say, at BB&T, everybody in our company has to have a growth mindset. And so by having a growth mindset and our commitment to empowerment and pushing down authority and responsibility, we're constantly bringing up people into the organizations. And as people below you come up and that allow you to move up and the whole organization is growing through that process.

So this is a really, really powerful idea and is one that everybody you're going to hear from is working on. And I think you'll find it to be very, very refreshing and reassuring with regard to BB&T.

BB&T is a different kind of a company. We're a different kind of bank. We're building the new bank, and we're building it in a context of our philosophy.

Before I close and let the program get started, I want to just remind you of one thing I've said last night. This is the day that all of us have to make the world a better place to live. Don't forget the power of one. Power of one is about living every day as if it is what it is which is the God-given day you have to make a difference in the world. Don't get in the trap of worrying about yesterday. Don't fall into the trap of waiting for tomorrow. You can't change yesterday and tomorrow is not promised, this is it, this is your day. Treat every person with dignity and respect that they deserve and realize the reality of life, the essence of life is about the fact that we interact with people, our families, our friends, our coworkers, people we don't even know, we interact with them all the time and every one of those interactions is an opportunity for us to make a difference. And as you make a difference in those individuals' lives, then you make a difference in the world. The butterfly effect in (inaudible) seems to happen, that you'll never even be able to imagine and maybe never even know, because you took the time, you made the effort to try to make a special positive meaningful impact on the lives of those people.

Power of one has a really incredibly important concept to keep in mind, and I hope you will do that. So thank -- again, thank you all for joining us. We're really excited about the day. We'll all be around as we take breaks for questions. You're going to see a dynamic team. I am so proud of each and every one of our team. You're going to see some of us that have been around for a while. You're going to see a lot of new faces, new folks that are really, really adding major contributions to our company. And I think you'll enjoy every bit of it. And then, at the very end of the presentation before we go into Q&A, this afternoon, which I hope you'll stay for, we are all going to hold questions till the end. Where we'll take all of the time you want to cover questions this afternoon, but I will tell you at the last presentation Daryl is going to be providing with -- for you some enhanced and improved long-term performance goals as we reflected on the recent changes in our environment. So we're off to a good day. Let's talk about BB&T building the new bank. Chris?

CHRISTOPHER LEE HENSON, PRESIDENT & COO, BB&T CORPORATION: All right. Good morning. Pleasure to be with you all and give you a strategic overview of the company. And when I'm finished, I hope that you will take away 4 primary messages: One, we operate in differentiated and diversified franchise in great markets. We are, in fact, maintaining our performance advantage of long term. We are, as Kelly said, reconceptualizing our business, so we're going to talk a lot about that today. And we have a deep and experienced leadership team and hopefully, you'll get to experience that firsthand. You know we do operate a differentiated set of businesses that really provides or strive for top-tier performance. So this business has really come together to produce diversification. It offers really stable, consistent and strong earnings growth. We set some targets over the last several years of cost savings. We have achieved those and it's through intense focus on expense control. Expense control is a huge part of Disrupt or Die. Disrupt or Die is really about, as you just heard Kelly say, taking costs out of our existing company, the old company, if you will, to reinvest in and build the new company, all while maintaining a strong focus on the client. You're going to hear that threaded throughout the day. But focus on maintaining a strong disciplined credit culture, achieving operating leverage on a consistent basis, at the same time, a strong and consistent dividend with a strong TSR. With the driving force behind all of this for us is to execute on our vision, mission and values. You heard a lot about that last night and that's under client support of everything we do.

So let's take a look at the franchise. As you know, we operate a Community Banking Model, and we've been doing for about 30 years. We've operated diversified set of businesses throughout the country on a national basis. The company was founded in 1872, eighth largest deposits institutional -- financial institution by deposits. Fifth largest insurance broker and we are broker, no underwritings but a broker in the United States and in the world. Second highest mobile application ranking in the industry. Over 1,900 bank locations and just over 36,000 FTEs serving 7.6 million clients.

If we look at our banking franchise. We operate primarily in 15 states. Part well, 15 states. Primarily, in 12 or 13 because we just spilled over into Indiana and Ohio with 2 to 3 offices. But we have top 5 market share in the primary operating states, about half of those. If you look at our weighted average GDP growth in our footprint, it really gives you a view inside our markets. So over 3 years compared to our peers, our markets have grown second fastest, 3.8% average GDP growth over that period of time.

We also are in 8 of the 10 -- top 10 cities for economic opportunity in our banking footprint. This is really the differentiating slide as a part of our strategy and how we run our company. It's really about diversification. You can see on the left, our diversification of revenue by segment and leads to the performance differentiation on the right. So finally the largest is the Community Bank-Retail makes up 44% of revenue; Commercial 23%; Financial Services 17%; and Insurance Holdings 16%. But the most important point is what it does for us on the right side. In the upper left, you can see a pretax, pre-provision net revenue over total assets for 10 years has grown faster than our national peers and the top 4 banks and we've done it, as you see in the lower right, with less volatility. So faster doing PPNR, less volatility, really result of running a diversified business and that is a key strategic difference for us.

This takes a look at our business. I'm not going to cover all of this, but give you a sort of quick rundown what the businesses bring to BB&T? It's important to understand what they do. But it's also more important to understand what they bring us.

Insurance Holdings provides the largest non-interest income provider we have, provides just under $2 billion in revenue and it provides a broader product array. It helps differentiate our business and helps us act as a trusted advisor. Many times, our bankers use this product as the lead product, they call on a prospect. It happens every day. The revenue stream is very diversified, because it's not sensitive to interest rates nor is it subject to dynamics of the credit cycle. So on a downturn, this business generally stands tall and very helpful. A complementary business to insurance is AFCO/CAFO, which is one of largest insurance premium finance businesses in the country that we operate. You'll hear John Howard talk more about those 2 later today. BB&T securities, in that broker deal, we operate really 2 businesses: BB&T Investment Services, which serves our consumer investment needs for our consumer product -- clients throughout the footprint. And it's primarily only annuities and mutual funds. Then we also operate Scott & Stringfellow, our full-service brokerage business. Interesting, 5, 6 years ago, we were in 2 or 3 states. Today, we're in all of our primary operating states. We've grown this business much faster on purpose to support our growing wealth business. We'll talk more about that in a moment. They're actually -- Scott's actually growing about 15% year-to-date.

If you look at Grandbridge, it's our national commercial real estate and multifamily business. It does finance and does it through third-party placements primarily, but also some on balance sheet financing. So what it brings us is really strong fee income to place in a secondary market and some on balance sheet net interest income. And Rufus Yates will talk to you more about those businesses. Regional Acceptance is our sub-prime into a smaller extent near prime out of the finance business and what it brings us is really strong risk-adjusted yields in a controlled operating structure.

Sheffield is our small take at equivalent finance. You saw a kiosk outside, it does UTVs like you saw there, it does jet skis, motorcycles, et cetera. And then Commercial Equipment Capital provides equipment financing nearly under [250] for small businesses.

The point I would make about those Sheffield and CEC is they're national, but they're also point of sale businesses. So as a consumer demand changes, the point of sale purchase in finance, we think it provides real good upside in revenue growth, again, national business. And Brant will walk you through more detail about that.

These are the recognitions, I'll just state a few, 24 Greenwich Excellence Award in Small Business and Middle Market for overall satisfaction and outstanding service. At the bottom, we will probably just name Best for Core Deposit Growth Strategy. The 2018 Bank Director Ranking and it's result of growing DDA, and you'll hear more about that today Dynatrace named us as the second highest mobile app ranking in the industry.

This looks at the -- right on this page, I think it's important page. Major accomplishments over the last 4 years since our last Investor Day. Part of one of our biggest accomplishments is the developing more digital capability when the primary items there as we launched our U platform and digital blanking platform, consistently ranked in the top 5 in the industry. We've integrated 5 acquisitions: Bank of Kentucky, Susquehanna, National PENN, 2 of our 4 largest insurance acquisitions. When it drill down into how we're executing on Disrupt or Die. I mean, you heard Kelly talk about that last night. You heard him cover this slide. I'm not going to cover this in detail, because you've seen it before. But I will make 2 primary points with you. Yes, we are going through unprecedented change right now with technology. No question about it. But if we were in -- today, anyone of those prior four stages, we would've said the exact same thing. We're going through unprecedented change.

The point is, we had opportunities and took advantage of opportunities at each one of those time periods, and we feel the exact same way about the one today.

The leadership team we had in place then for the most part is still in place today. The core of Disrupt or Die is really about reconceptualizing our business, as I said earlier, to reinvest and -- or take cost out of our existing company or kind of our old company to reinvest in and build our new company. I'll give you two examples. If you look at the top left, it's really about optimizing the branch strategy. So we took out 148 branches last year, we're going to do 171 this year, 150 or so next year. So total of about 20% reduction in our branches over a 3-year period.

If you look at the upper right, we've also been focused in at the same time on our nonbranch facilities. So we've reduced square footage in our non-branches. Last year, 7.2%, 4.9% this year 4.7%. And a little less than 4%, we anticipate next year. We already have bate on next year. A total of a 16% reduction in square footage in the backroom, which is huge. We anticipate reducing our electricity usage about 20% to 25%. And we're going to take a portion of those dollars then and reinvest in opportunities that you see around that page.

One of the primary ones that we made a lot of impact as I alluded to earlier, is digital. I mentioned that we're in the top 5 generally in almost all publications and we were ranked for our U platform. And I think it's because we have continued to iterate new enhancements every quarter and to keep it fresh. Last quarter, it was about new card controls. A quarter before that, it was about a new personal financial management tool for our wealth clients. And so the objective is to keep it fresh and relevant and we continue to invest in it.

We also -- beginning this year through DontÃ¡'s leadership to roll out something we call, Voice of the Client, which is a new digital platform that helps all of our businesses. Again, roll out, beginning this year, all through the -- into next.

It gives our businesses near real-time client feedback, which helps them better run their business and informs them on what digital investments to make in the future.

We also made substantial improvement in our social media, messaging and also our digital marketing.

On the lower left, in insurance. We have a number of initiatives underway, improving the performance and profitability of insurance.

One of the ones that I will point out is robotics, which started 6 to 9 months ago, really digging into how we might improve a real paper-based industry still today. And through that, we have an implementation going in that we expect is going to save us significant dollars in 2019.

Refocusing on the Community Bank. About a year ago, fourth quarter last year, it became crystal clear to us that we had rich opportunities to really bring value out of the Community Bank. For example, this branch rationalization strategy takes a lot of time. It's really intense. Investing in new branches and growth opportunities, new marketing, be it digital or direct mail and a vast new -- a number of new products, which you're going to hear Brant walk you through. Or in commercial, where we're standing up with Financial Insights program, remaking how we deliver small business, real focus behind SBA lending and ABL lending.

So what we did is that we thought it made sense to double down in executive leadership in the Community Banks. So we asked Brant Standridge to come in the beginning of this year, lead the retail segment. So those 2 fellows work with me to ensure that we still present a unified Community Bank model to our associates, but also how we face the community, and it's going exceptionally well.

We've been really pleased with the cost that we've been able to take out of the business and the improvement in efficiency. Things like we just talk about. The branch, the rationalization strategy, the nonbranch facilities, implementation of robotics, where we're really just in our infancy we're just getting started tremendous opportunity. Last year, we had a systemwide restructure. We took out 1,600 FTEs, about 4% or 4.5% of our workforce. And while we have a boss that gives [us a use] of consultants, we thought in the vein of turning over every rock, because we were darn serious about making this happen. We did decide to bring in outside assistance to help us stand up 4 new projects. And I'd like to introduce and walk you through those today.

The first is technology. So we brought in consultant to help Barbara and her team really begin to look at the business and technology and how we support the businesses from top to bottom. Started with organization review, went through the spans and layers review, reducing layers, increasing spans, taking cost out we're going to use some of that money to reinvest and while we are happy with our agile effort, there is much more we can do with agile and standing up DevOps to push it throughout the company. Also looking at implementing lean principles to do what we do more efficiently and took a hard look at our vendor relationships to take cost out. So we are clearly taking cost out in technology and Barbara will walk you through that transformation, but very, very pleased with what we're doing to align the business to be more business focused and aligned.

Secondly, John Howard and his team brought in an consultant in April of this year and really the objective was to look at the business from top to bottom. No holds barred. And that entailed a review of the operating models from wholesale and retail. It involved looking at the backroom of still a paper-based industry to automate what we can. And I would say that we have automation going in every single entity in some form or fashion in insurance today.

Secondly or thirdly, really looking at how the corporation interacts with this large business. If you think about it, insurance is larger in its industry than BB&T is in its industry. And how we interact is key so that we allow them to be nimble and flexible to be able to take advantage of opportunities in an entrepreneurial industry. At the same time, bringing the heft to BB&T to provide shared services where it makes sense, where we have expertise like data and analytics, real estate services, et cetera. So the purpose here is to unlock value for the next 2 to 3 years and there has never been a time that I've been associated with insurance business that I feel better about the improved profitability potential we have over the next 2 to 3 years. And John will walk you through his transformation later.

Thirdly, beginning in August of this year, we brought in a consultant to help us do a deep dive on organizational simplification projects. So we're starting at the top of the house, layer by layer, going through our management structure, reducing layers, increasing spans of control to design an operating structure that is more efficient and to help us make better and faster decisions in this company so that we would be more nimble. It's tough. We're about halfway through it. We'll finish it in the first quarter, but it's absolutely worth it. And it will make us better for having gone through it.

And then finally, we're redesigning our commercial lending process from end to end, truly when we -- from when we make the first call on the client to when the last loan is paid off at the end of that pay period. And the purpose here is really to simplify the process for our associates, our clients, to enhance revenue and to take out cost. And while all of these have cost implications, this has -- about 2/3 of this opportunity, we believe, is revenue as we get our audience more focused on their targets.

So this process, we just started in fourth quarter. It will continue through the fourth quarter of next year. So you can see 4 significant impactful projects we started at the beginning of this year will roll through the end of next year that will make a significant difference, we believe in our company, enable us to reinvest more heavily in our company long term.
